Yeah, the right tyres make a huge difference for off roading, especially when mud, sand and snow get involved. I don’t think most people realise just how much tyres affect performance, even on dry asphalt.

I’d hope something like the cybertruck has sufficiently advanced traction control that it wouldn’t be necessary anyway. Some kind of ‘low-range’/crawl mode where the sensitivity of the accelerator pedal is reduced would also be useful.

You can’t make a tyre that’s good for every situation. There are trade-offs in fuel economy vs grip, softness vs durability etc. You can’t really blame Tesla for not inventing an impossible tyre when they can’t even invent a truck that looks good.
But this does look like it’s sitting on top of the snow, so it likely comes back to the wrong tyres (or maybe cybertrucks just don’t like cold weather).

It’s kind of situation dependent - less ground pressure if you’re driving over the top of soft packed snow, more if you’re driving through a loose covering and sinking through it down to hard packed/frozen snow, ice or even asphalt/gravel underneath.

For example, try doing a search for ‘Zara dress’. Every single organic search result is from Zara. If users were getting these results from simply searching for ‘dress’ people would catch on pretty quick that something was wrong.

Additionally, I think the analysis in this wired article is only partially correct. If Google was actually adding brand names to search queries then all the organic results would be from the brand in question. It’s more likely that they only do this for the ad results, not the organic results.

In situations like this, where Google doesn’t have good results but does know that the words searched are related to other entities, it will show results for the closest match - in this case coverage discussing trans weightlifter Laurel Hubbard.
Additionally searching for “intersex weightlifter” with quotes doesn’t turn up many results, meaning Google hasn’t indexed this exact string anywhere. /cont
